title: Conditional Side Effects
subject: React
theory:
## Controlling Execution
You cannot put `useEffect` inside an `if` statement. But you can put `if` statements inside `useEffect`.

### Logic
If you want an effect to run only when `user.isAdmin` is true:
`useEffect(() => { if (!isAdmin) return; ... }, [isAdmin])`.

examples.output: Fetches only when user types 3+ chars.

common_mistakes.correction: If you use `searchQuery` inside, it MUST be in dependency array. Use the 'if' check to prevent execution, not the array omission.

summary: Precise control of side effects prevents bugs and performance issues.
